title: Question 10

children: A 25-year-old man is evaluated for a 2-day history of a rapidly spreading pruritic rash on his chest, back, upper arms and legs. Medical history is significant for acne vulgaris treated with tretinoin cream. He started sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim for his acne 9 days ago.
The rash on his back is
shown

The rash is also found on his neck, chest, and proximal limbs. Conjunctivae, oral mucosa, and urethral meatus are normal, and there are no oral lesions. Anterior and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy is present. The remainder of the examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Exanthematous or morbilliform (measles-like) eruptions are the most common form of cutaneous drug reactions, usually appearing within the first or second week of drug exposure.

An exanthematous rash begins as erythematous papules and macules that coalesce symmetrically to form plaques, beginning on the trunk and progressing distally across the limbs and usually sparing the palms and soles.
The most likely diagnosis is exanthematous drug eruption (
Option B

). This patient presents with a morbilliform rash 9 days after starting sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim, a frequent cause of medication reactions. Exanthematous or morbilliform (measles-like) eruptions are the most common form of cutaneous drug reactions, most likely representing a type IV delayed hypersensitivity reaction. The rash appears during the first or second week after drug exposure, although subsequent exposures can produce a reaction much more quickly. Patients develop erythematous papules and macules that coalesce symmetrically to form plaques, beginning on the trunk and progressing distally across the limbs and usually sparing the palms and soles. The papules are often dense and monomorphic and are accompanied by varying degrees of pruritus. Lymphadenopathy is not uncommon. Treatment involves cessation of the causative agent, use of potent topical glucocorticoids, and oral H
antihistamines. A widespread rash may make the topical application of glucocorticoids impractical, and systemic glucocorticoid therapy may be required.
Drug-induced hypersensitivity syndrome (DIHS) (
Option A

), formerly called drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS), is a severe life-threatening medication reaction. Symptoms begin with fever and flulike symptoms, which are quickly followed by burning skin pain and rash. The rash is typically a morbilliform exanthem that starts on the face and upper trunk and spreads distally. Eventually, patients develop striking facial edema and redness, a hallmark of this condition, as
shown

Oral mucosal involvement is common. Unlike other severe medication reactions, the onset of symptoms in DIHS is delayed, often 2 to 6 weeks after exposure. The rash onset after 9 days and lack of systemic symptoms in this patient are inconsistent with DIHS.
A fixed drug eruption (
Option C

) presents with one to several dusky purple-pink macules or plaques, most commonly on the lips, face, fingers, and genitals. They may occur within the first 2 weeks of starting a causative medication but are localized, including when they recur upon re-exposure. The diffuse rash in this patient is inconsistent with a fixed drug reaction.
Hypersensitivity vasculitis (
Option D
) also occurs within 2 weeks of drug exposure but manifests as palpable purpura and not the diffuse rash seen in this patient.

references: Kroshinsky D. Adverse cutaneous reactions to medications [Editorial]. Clin Dermatol. 2020;38:605-6.
